definition[0]: to make something seem better, larger, worse etc than it really is
example[0]: I couldn’t sleep for three days – I’m not exaggerating.
example[1]: It’s difficult to exaggerate the importance of sleep.
collocation[0]: it is difficult/hard/impossible to exaggerate something
example[2]: It is difficult to exaggerate the strength of people’s feelings on this matter.
collocation[1]: it is easy to exaggerate something
example[3]: It’s all too easy to exaggerate the importance of these rather minor factors.
example[4]: Personally, I think society exaggerates the importance of marriage.
example[5]: The army exaggerated the extent to which the operation was a success.
example[6]: We believe the Chancellor is exaggerating the impact these proposals will have.
example[7]: I’m sure Tommy is exaggerating the size of the problem.
example[8]: He yawned widely, exaggerating the effect by stretching his arms wide.
definition[1]: to say that something is much bigger, better, worse, more important etc than it really is
example[11]: The grass in the garden was about three feet high – I’m not exaggerating.
display[0]: blow something (up) out of all proportion
definition[2]: to say a situation or event is a lot worse or much more serious than it really is
example[12]: The problem really has been blown up out of all proportion.
definition[3]: to treat something that has happened as though it were more important or serious than it really is – used especially when saying that you should not do this
example[13]: She loved the fact that he’d sent her flowers, but she didn’t want to make too much of it in case it meant nothing.
example[14]: It's probably nothing – children often get these strange ideas. You shouldn’t make too much of them
definition[4]: to say that a part of something is more important and has a bigger effect than is really true, especially in relation to other things
example[15]: The importance of cleanliness in the preparation of food cannot be overemphasized.
example[16]: Historians have tended to overemphasize the role of the monarchy in British history.
definition[5]: to describe something in a way that makes it sound more important or serious than it really is
example[18]: The importance of advertising can hardly be overstated.
definition[6]: to make something seem more important than it is, in the way that you talk about it or treat it
example[19]: The media has greatly overplayed this issue.
definition[7]: to make someone or something seem much better, less harmful etc than they really are – used when you think it is wrong to do this
example[22]: These images were produced in order to glorify the empire.
definition[8]: to talk about something in a way that makes it appear more important, interesting, or successful than it really is, especially to get someone’s support or interest
example[23]: At the interview, he talked up his experience of working in sales.
example[24]: The government tried to talk up the threat posed by these countries, in order to justify an increase in military spending.
definition[9]: if you think someone or something is overrated, you think they are not nearly as good as people claim
example[25]: I think her books are overrated.
definition[10]: an idealized image, view, picture etc of someone or something shows them as being much better than they really are
example[27]: His books give an idealized picture of English rural life.
example[28]: her friend’s idealized view of marriage
